body.p: Suppose that P(A) = 0.99. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this statement?

input.choice: Event A will occur more often than not, but it is not extremely likely.
Event A is extremely likely, but in a long sequence of trials, it occasionally will not occur.

response.feedback: Incorrect. An event will always occur only if its probability is 1. Here, P(A) = 0.99, which means that the event will almost always occur, but after numerous repetitions, the event occasionally will not occur.

Incorrect. It is true that if P(A) = 0.99, then it will occur more often than not. However, it is incorrect that it is not extremely likely. P(A) = 0.99 is very close to 1, which indicates that event A is extremely likely, but after numerous repetitions, the event occasionally will not occur.
Correct. Since P(A) = 0.99 is very close to 1, then event A is extremely likely. In other words, event A will almost always occur, but occasionally, in a long sequence of trials, it will not occur.

Incorrect. An event will never occur if its probability is 0. Here, P(A) = 0.99 which is means that the event will almost always occur, but after numerous repetitions, the event occasionally will not occur.

body.p: Suppose that P(A) = 0.30. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this statement?

input.choice: Event A will occur less often than not, but it is not extremely unlikely.
Event A is extremely unlikely, but it will occur once in awhile in a long sequence of trials.

response.feedback: Incorrect. An event will always occur only if its probability is 1. Here, P(A) = 0.30 which is means that event A will not frequently occur.
Correct. Since P(A) = 0.30 is less the 0.50, event A will occur less often than not. Since the probability of 0.30 is not very close to 0, event A is not extremely unlikely.
Incorrect. It is true that since P(A) = 0.30 is less than 0.50, it will not frequently occur. However, an event that occurs 30% of the time is not highly unlikely.
Incorrect. An event will never occur only if its probability is 0. Here, P(A) = 0.30 which means that event A will not frequently occur.

body.p: Which of the following valid probabilities represents an event that is impossible?

response.feedback: Incorrect. By definition probabilities can not be less than zero or more than one so this is not a valid probability.
Correct. An event with a probability of 0 is impossible: it cannot happen!

Incorrect. You may have selected this choice because the probability is very small. However, the event is still possible (while very unlikely) if the probability is 0.0001. Note that the event described is impossible.
Incorrect. An event with probability 1 is an event that is certain, that is, it always happens. Note that the event described is impossible.

body.p: Which of the following probabilities could describe an event that is likely but not certain?

response.feedback: Incorrect. An event with a probability of 0.2 is less likely to happen than one with an even chance (50-50), so it could not describe a likely event.
Incorrect. An event with a probability of 0.5 is equally likely to happen or not happen, so it would not be a good way to describe an event which is likely.
Correct. An event with probability more than 0.5 and less than 1 is considered to be likely.
Incorrect. You may have selected this answer because an event with probability 1 is certain, but the question specifies that the event is not certain. There is a better answer.
